statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.description: Kenny Thomas, playing his first game since being suspended three games for fighting, scored 23 points, including six in overtime, to help the Houston Rockets beat the Golden State Warriors 100-96.
article.headline: After suspension, Thomas comes back with flurry
article.linkText: Thomas comes back strong, lifting Rockets past Warriors
article.story:
HOUSTON (AP) -- Kenny Thomas didn't feel that different when he got to the arena on Tuesday night. But Thomas, playing his first game since being suspended three games for fighting, scored 23 points, including six in overtime, to help the Houston Rockets beat the Golden State Warriors 100-96. "Everybody was asking me if I felt anxious tonight, but I thought I was pretty much myself," said Thomas, who also had eight rebounds. "When I got up this morning, I thought I was going to be anxious because I haven't played in three games. But I felt pretty much the same." The Rockets thought differently. Thomas played both ends well, guarding Bob Sura at the end of regulation when Sura missed a running jumper at the buzzer that would have won the game. In the overtime, the Rockets took the ball inside to Thomas, who hit all three of his shots and had an assist to Kelvin Cato for two other points. "Kenny was great," said Steve Francis, who had 33 points and 12 rebounds. "Coach saw we had an advantage with him going against Antawn (Jamison), who was rusty coming off the bench late. We exploited that real good." Coach Rudy Tomjanovich was impressed. "Kenny was phenomenal," Tomjanovich said. "He played defense well and was really focused in the overtime." Thomas is just glad the coaches believe in him. "They have a lot of trust in me now," Thomas said. "That feels good. They are going to me in the fourth quarter, and they've never done that before." The Warriors led by as many as 13 in the fourth quarter, but coach Brian Winters surprisingly chose to play guard Jason Richardson, who led the team with 14 points the first three quarters, only one minute in the last period. "There wasn't anything wrong with him," Winters said of Richardson. "We were kind of rolling right along with a 10-point lead and 2-to-3 minutes left. I had the veterans in the game. I wanted to play them down the stretch. It didn't work out, but I wanted to play the guys with the most experience. J.R. had been sitting on the bench and would have been cold. "We didn't make shots down the stretch and we turned then ball over. That's a double combination that's going to get you beat most nights, and it did tonight. This is probably the most heart-breaking loss of the year." Larry Hughes scored 17 and Jason Richardson 16 for the Warriors, who have lost 14 of 15 on the road. "Late in the game, we got real conservative and let the clock run down and we didn't get good shots," Hughes said. "We just didn't finish them off." Moochie Norris, who hit a 3-pointer to tie it with 13 seconds remaining in regulation, hit two free throws with 29 seconds to play and Francis added a free throw with 15 seconds left to seal the victory. The Rockets won consecutive games for the first time since Nov. 6-8. They beat Charlotte in overtime Saturday. The Warriors were ahead 86-76 on a basket by Erick Dampier with three minutes to play in regulation. Houston then went on a 10-0 run that tied it at 86 on Norris' 3-pointer from the corner. Thomas scored seven unanswered points in the first quarter to give the Rockets to a 21-15 lead with 3:01 to play. Richardson's eight points helped Golden State keep it close as Houston led 27-23 after one. Richardson and Chris Mills each had eight at the half as Golden State pulled ahead 47-46 on a follow shot by Hughes with six seconds remaining. Francis had 10 at the half. The Warriors outscored the Rockets 11-2 midway through the third quarter to take their biggest lead at 65-56 with 2:41 remaining in the period. Entering the fourth, Golden State led 67-60 and Richardson led the way with 14 points. The Warriors scored the first six points of the fourth quarter to open a 73-60 lead with 9:47 to play.

Game notes
Kelvin Cato's 11 rebounds for Houston gave him five consecutive games with double-figure rebounding for the first time in his career. ... Warriors backup guard Gilbert Arenas missed the game with tonsillitis. ... The Warriors are 6-14 since Brian Winters took over as interim head coach Dec. 15.
